elements.content: The secondary building unit (SBU) has been identified as a useful tool in the synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Herein, we synthesized six novel Zn complexes, namely, {[Zn3(tci)2(DMF)2)]·2DMF·2CH3OH} n (1), {[Zn3(tci)2(DMSO)2(H2O)2]·2DMSO·3H2O} n (2), {[ZnNa­(tci)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (3), {[Zn5(tci)2(OH)4(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (4), {[Zn3(tci)2(phen)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (5), and {[Zn3(tci)2(btb)2(H2O)2]·6H2O} n (6) by utilizing different SBUs (tci = tris­(2-carboxyethyl) isocyanurate, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, btb = 1,4-bis (1,2,4-triazole-1-ylmethyl) benzene). Complexes 1–4 were synthesized only by changing solvents, and complexes 5 and 6 were obtained by adding different auxiliary ligands on the same conditions. Structural analyses show that complexes 1 and 2 possess two-dimensional (2D) structures based on linear and triangular trinuclear Zn clusters. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit 2D and three-dimensional (3D) frameworks built on rare infinite rod-shaped SBUs, while complex 5 belongs to a 3D framework with two kinds of left- and right-helical chains built from discrete dinuclear Zn clusters and mononuclear Zn atoms. Complex 6 exhibits high-connected 3D framework based on extended linear trinuclear Zn clusters.

elements.content: The secondary building unit (SBU) has been identified as a useful tool in the synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs). By using different SBUs, a series of Zn complexes with different structures are synthesized. Rare infinite Zn clusters and Zn−Na cluster chains (rod-shaped SBUs) containing in the frameworks are also reported.

elements.content: In recent years, much of the initial interest and enthusiasm has focused on the assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) not only because of their aesthetics of crystalline architectures but also due to their potential applications as new materials such as magnetism, luminescence, catalysis, and gas storage. In particular, structures constructed from secondary building units (SBUs) and organic linkers have been shown to be amenable to systematic variation. Under the guidance of crystal engineering, the SBUs are considered as the “joints” and the organic linkers as the “struts” of the underlying net. Because of the suitable size and multiple coordination sites, SBUs are a kind of significant building subunit in the crystal engineering of MOFs. The successful application of this approach has led to significant implications for the design of diverse MOFs containing discrete SBUs shapes such as triangles, squares, and tetrahedra as well as rare infinite rod-shaped SBUs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, much of the initial interest and enthusiasm has focused on the assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) not only because of their aesthetics of crystalline architectures but also due to their potential applications as new materials such as magnetism, luminescence, catalysis, and gas storage. In particular, structures constructed from secondary building units (SBUs) and organic linkers have been shown to be amenable to systematic variation. Under the guidance of crystal engineering, the SBUs are considered as the "joints" and the organic linkers as the "struts" of the underlying net. Because of the suitable size and multiple coordination sites, SBUs are a kind of significant building subunit in the crystal engineering of MOFs. The successful application of this approach has led to significant implications for the design of diverse MOFs containing discrete SBUs shapes such as triangles, squares, and tetrahedra as well as rare infinite rod-shaped SBUs.

elements.content: For constructing appropriate SBUs, the key factor is the selection of organic ligands which play a crucial role in constructing desired MOFs. In comparison to common organic ligands, multidentate ligands could connect more than one metal to increase the multinuclearity of the complex and expand the dimension of MOFs. Moreover, carboxylates have been proven to be efficient ligands displaying multiple bridging modes like η1, η1:η1, μ2-η2, μ2-η2:η1, μ3-η2:η1, μ3-η2:η2, μ4-η2:η2, μ5-η3:η3, syn-syn-μ2-η1:η1, anti-anti-μ2-η1:η1, and syn-anti-μ2-η1:η1 (Scheme ). Among the numerous carboxylate ligands, the flexible multifunctional carboxylic acid ligands which hold multiple coordination sites are capable of bending and rotating freely and act as bridging or chelating ligands to form prospective SBUs and sequentially extend into a high-dimensional framework. Previously, we have reported a porous magnet based on discrete tetranuclear copper units as SBUs and two porous Cu-MOFs containing infinite copper chains as rod-shaped SBUs using a flexible tris­(2-carboxyethyl) isocyanurate (tci) ligand. Along with this work in such fields, herein, by changing solvent systems, temperature, and auxiliary ligands, we obtained six Zn-MOFs based on different SBUs. The complex {[Zn3(tci)2(DMF)2)]·2DMF·2CH3OH} n (1) is a porous two-dimensional (2D) structure built on linear trinuclear zinc clusters; the complex {[Zn3(tci)2(DMSO)2(H2O)2]·2DMSO·3H2O} n (2) possesses a 2D framework with triangular trinuclear Zn clusters; the complex {[ZnNa­(tci)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (3) shows a 2D framework with two distinct channels based on unfamiliar infinite Zn–O–Na rod-shaped SBUs; the complex {[Zn5(tci)2(OH)4(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (4) displays a three-dimensional (3D) framework based on infinite Zn–O–C rod-shaped SBUs; the complex {[Zn3(tci)2(phen)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (5) exhibits a 3D framework with two kinds of left- and right-helix chains built on discrete dinuclear zinc clusters, and the complex {[Zn3(tci)2(btb)2(H2O)2]·6H2O} n (6) has a high-connected 3D framework with (43)­(410·520·612·73) topology built from extended linear trinuclear Zn clusters. In addition, the thermal stabilities of 1–6 in the solid state have also been investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. IR data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the region of 400–4000 cm–1. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using CuKα radiation on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in air.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. IR data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the region of 400-4000 cm-1. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using CuKα radiation on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in air.

elements.content: A MeOH solution of Zn­(OAc)2 (10.95 mg in 3 mL) was carefully layered onto a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of H3tci (10.35 mg in 3 mL). After the solution was allowed to stand for about 7 days, the colorless crystals 1 formed were isolated in 73% yield by filtration. Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C38H60N10O24Zn3 (1237.07): C 36.89, H 4.88, N 11.32; found: C 36.19, H 4.42, N 11.12. IR: 3439s, 1690s, 1603m, 1470m, 1411m, 1251w, 1096w, 1021w, 963w, 766m, 531m.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction for crystal of 1 were performed using a Oxford Diffraction equipped with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and crystals of 2–6 were performed using Rigaku CrystalClear-SM Expert 2.0 diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), respectively. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction for crystal of 1 were performed using a Oxford Diffraction equipped with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and crystals of 2-6 were performed using Rigaku CrystalClear-SM Expert 2.0 diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), respectively. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn atoms, one tci ligand, two DMF molecules, and one discrete CH3OH molecule. As can be seen from Figure A, Zn1 is coordinated in an octahedron geometry, which is defined by six O atoms from two μ2-η1:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups, two μ2-η2:η1 bidentate tci ligands in the equatorial plane, and two O atoms from μ2-η1:η1 tci ligands in the apical position. Zn2 atom is coordinated to five O–donors from two μ2-η1:η1 bidentate ligands, one μ2-η2:η1 bidentate tci ligand, and one DMF molecule to furnish slightly distorted trigonal biyramid coordination geometry with addition trigonality factor τ = 0.53. The corresponding bond lengths and bond angles are listed in . In cis, cis, cis-conformation, each tci connects to six Zn atoms in two μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes and one μ2-η2:η1 coordination mode (Scheme a). Zn1 is linked to two Zn2 atoms via four μ2-η1:η1 bidetate carboxylate groups and two μ2-η2:η1 carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear Zn unit with the Zn1–Zn2 distance of 3.51 Å and the Zn(1)–O–Zn(2) bond angles of 102.87°. The trinuclear units as SBUs are united together by six tci ligands to give a 2D structure (Figure B). Viewed along the b axis, there is a tube completed by trinuclear units and face-to-face tci ligands (Figure C). It has internal dimensions of ca. 5.34 × 11.79 Å2 and the calculated free volume in the framework is 30.1% by PLATON. A better insight into the nature of this intriguing structure can be achieved by the application of a topology approach, reducing the complicated structures to simple nodes and connection nets. If the trinuclear Zn unit can be regarded as 6-connected node and tci ligand can be simplified as 3-connected node, the interesting 2D dimensional structure can be described as a (3,6)-connected net with point symbol of (43)­(83·46·66) (Figure D).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Zn3(tci)2(DMF)2)]⋅2DMF⋅2CH3OH} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn atoms, one tci ligand, two DMF molecules, and one discrete CH3OH molecule. As can be seen from Figure A, Zn1 is coordinated in an octahedron geometry, which is defined by six O atoms from two μ2-η1:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups, two μ2-η2:η1 bidentate tci ligands in the equatorial plane, and two O atoms from μ2-η1:η1 tci ligands in the apical position. Zn2 atom is coordinated to five O-donors from two μ2-η1:η1 bidentate ligands, one μ2-η2:η1 bidentate tci ligand, and one DMF molecule to furnish slightly distorted trigonal biyramid coordination geometry with addition trigonality factor τ = 0.53. The corresponding bond lengths and bond angles are listed in . In cis, cis, cis-conformation, each tci connects to six Zn atoms in two μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes and one μ2-η2:η1 coordination mode (Scheme a). Zn1 is linked to two Zn2 atoms via four μ2-η1:η1 bidetate carboxylate groups and two μ2-η2:η1 carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear Zn unit with the Zn1-Zn2 distance of 3.51 Å and the Zn(1)-O-Zn(2) bond angles of 102.87°. The trinuclear units as SBUs are united together by six tci ligands to give a 2D structure (Figure B). Viewed along the b axis, there is a tube completed by trinuclear units and face-to-face tci ligands (Figure C). It has internal dimensions of ca. 5.34 × 11.79 Å2 and the calculated free volume in the framework is 30.1% by PLATON. A better insight into the nature of this intriguing structure can be achieved by the application of a topology approach, reducing the complicated structures to simple nodes and connection nets. If the trinuclear Zn unit can be regarded as 6-connected node and tci ligand can be simplified as 3-connected node, the interesting 2D dimensional structure can be described as a (3,6)-connected net with point symbol of (43)(83⋅46⋅66) (Figure D).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P1̅. It is notable that there are two kinds of tci ligands A and B. The carboxylate groups of tci (A) coordinates with four zinc atoms in μ2-η2, η1 conformation (Scheme b1). While the carboxylate groups of tci (B) connects to six zinc atoms in μ2-η2 and μ2-η1:η1 conformation (Scheme b2). As depicted in Figure A, there are three independent Zn atoms. Zn1 in tetrahedron geometry coordinates with three oxygen atoms from three different tci ligands and one oxygen atom from DMSO molecule. Zn2 is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms of three tci ligands and one O atom of water molecule, taking slightly distorted tetrahedron coordination geometry. Zn3 shows an octahedron geometry which is completed by four carboxylate groups, one water molecule, and one DMSO molecule. Zn1 is linked to Zn3 via two carboxylate groups, and Zn3 is also linked to Zn2 via two carboxylate groups forming a trinuclear Zn cluster. However, the arrangement of the trinuclear Zn cluster in 2 is significantly different from that in complex 1. The trinuclear Zn SBU in 2 is shaped like a triangle, while the trinuclear Zn SBU in 1 feature as a line type. The trinuclear Zn SBUs are further connected through two different kinds of tci ligands (tci A with Zn atoms shows a 1D double chain and tci B with Zn atoms features a 1D double chain) to furnish a 2D framework (Figure B,C). Further topological analyses performed by the OLEX program indicate that the framework of 2 could also be classified as a (3,6)-connected topology with point symbol of (83·46·66)­(43)2, if the trinuclear cluster, tci A and B are defined as 6-connected node and 3-connected nodes (Figure D). To the best of our knowledge, the MOF with such a net topology is unusual, despite its apparent simplicity and the common occurrence of 3- and 6-connecting nodes.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 3 crystallize in monoclinic space group P2/c. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn atom, one Na atom, and one tci ligand as well as three water molecules. Zn is coordinated four oxygen atoms from four individual carboxylate groups in μ3-η2:η1 conformation and one water molecule displaying distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry (τ = 0.88). Na shows octahedron geometry which is surrounded by five oxygen atoms from five individual tci ligands and one oxygen atom from the ring of the tci ligand (Figure a). The three carboxylate groups of tci ligand link four Zn atoms and five Na atoms via μ3-η2:η1 conformation. It is necessary to note that an infinite Zn–Na chain with Zn···Na separation of 3.486 Å is exhibited in the structure (Figure B). As a matter of fact, reports on this infinite Zn–Na chain as rod-shaped SBUs are rare to date. The connectivity between Zn–Na chains and tci ligands leads to the formation of a 2D double layer. It is interesting to find that there are two types of channels with different sizes along the b axis (Figure C). The crystallographic dimensions of the big channel are 8.318 × 5.335 Å2, while internal dimensions of the small channel are 4.214 × 7.216 Å2. Thus the guest water molecule can be encapsulated in the big channels. Adjacent 2D layers are connected by hydrogen bonding into a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: X-ray structural analysis reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 4 consists of one tci ligand, two and a half crystallographically independent Zn atoms, two μ3-OH groups, one coordinated water molecule, and one discrete water molecule. As shown in Figure A, Zn1 exhibits trigonal bipyramid geometry which is coordinated by two bidentate carboxylate O atoms from two different tci ligands and three μ3-OH groups. Zn2 is surrounded by six oxygen atoms, two of the oxygen atoms being from the tci units in the apical position and the rest come from μ3-OH groups on the equatorial plane to give overall distorted octahedron geometry around the metal center. Zn3 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two individual tci ligands, one μ3-OH group, and one oxygen atom from a water molecule displaying distorted tetrahedron geometry. The Zn–O bond lengths fall in the range of 1.955–2.214 Å. In Scheme d, the tci ligand adopts a cis, cis, trans-conformation in quadridentate coordination mode, of which two carboxylate groups take syn, syn-μ2 :η 1 conformation, and the third carboxylate group takes η1 conformation. All of the Zn atoms are bridged by the μ3 oxygen atoms. And it is interesting to find that an infinite Zn cluster chain is formed (Figure B). The distances between the zinc centers are Zn1–Zn2 3.099, Zn1–Zn3 3.196, Zn1–Zn3 3.653, Zn1–Zn1B 3.203 Å. The cluster chains as SBUs (SBUs) are bridged by tci ligands to give a 3D framework (Figure C). To date, MOFs constructed from such infinite rod-shaped SBUs remain largely unexplored.

elements.content: Compound 5 displays a 3D framework. It contains three individual Zn atoms, two different tci ligands, two different phen auxiliary ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and four lattice guest water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure A, Zn1 shows square pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.32) which is coordinated by three oxygen atoms of three tci ligands and two N atoms of one phen. Zn2 lies in a distorted octahedron coordination environment, defined by three O atoms of three tci ligands and two water molecules. Zn3 is five-coordinated which is completed by three oxygen atoms from two tci ligands and two nitrogen atoms from one phen. There are also two kinds of tci ligands A and B. The carboxylate groups in A adopt η1, η1 and syn-anti-μ2-η1:η1 conformation bridging four Zn atoms (Scheme e1), while the carboxylate groups of another tci ligand B coordinates with Zn atoms in η1, μ2-η2:η1 and η1:η1 (Scheme e2). Another attractive structural feature of 5 is both A and B connecting with Zn atoms form two groups of right- and left-handed helical chains. As shown in Figure B, these helical chains are arranged in left-handed (A) and right-handed (B) sequences by turns but run parallel to each other. Each left-handed (A) helical chain is connected with two left-handed helical chains (B) above and below and two right-handed helical chains (A) on the left and right sides. All of the helical pitches are 7.7641 Å corresponding to the length of b-axis. The helices are connected alternately and united together to afford a 3D framework. Phen are encapsulated filling in the pores. To the best of our knowledge, such a complex which contains two groups of left-handed and right-handed helical chains is rarely reported. If we define the dinuclear Zn cluster as 4-connected node, two tci ligands as 3-connected nodes, the 3D framework of 5 can be described as a (3,4)-connected topology with a point symbol of (83)2(84·122) (Figure C).

elements.content: When the long and flexible btb ligand was introduced into the synthesis of 5, a 3D self-penetrating architecture was isolated. As depicted in Figure A, there are two independent Zn­(II) atoms in 6. Zn1 is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from tci ligands and one nitrogen atoms from btb showing tetrahedron geometry. Zn2 displays distorted octahedron coordination geometry, ligated by two oxygen atoms from tci, two oxygen atoms from water molecules, and two nitrogen atoms from two btb ligands. Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are linked together by two carboxylate group in syn, anti-μ2-η1:η1 to give an extended linear trinuclear SBU. As shown in Figure F, the carboxylate groups adopt η1 and syn, anti-μ2-η1:η1 conformation mode to link trinuclear SBUs forming a 2D layer (Figure B). And interestingly, there are two kinds of btb ligands. Both the btb ligand adopt trans- conformation and the dihedral angles between the planes of triazole ring and benzene ring in these two kinds of btb ligands are different. The dihedral angles are 80.594° and 79.975° for N10 in btb and N7 in btb, respectively. Besides, Zn2 ions are linked by N7 containing btb to form an infinite zigzag chain with the Zn···Zn separation of 13.012 Å (Figure B), while N10 containing btb with Zn1 forms a single unit. And then the chains act as pillars connecting with the layers to generate a 3D framework (Figure C). Better insight into the framework can be assessed by the topology. The tci ligand and the linear trinuclear Zn SBU can be regarded as three-connected node and ten-connected node. Therefore, the 3D network of 6 can be described as a 3,10-connected topology with a point symbol of (43)­(410·520·612·73).

elements.content: The prediction of polymer structures is still subjective and cannot be generalized because the final structures are frequently modulated by various factors, such as solvent, the metal and ligand nature, temperature, templates, and so on. Even for the same ligand and metal ion, changes in reaction conditions may give rise to the changes in the structural dimensionality of the products. Compared with the normal ligands, flexible ligands are very easy to be affected by the reaction conditions and have a tendency to generate different products even upon very little alteration of the reaction conditions. Herein, owing to the three flexible propionic acid groups, the tci molecule is capable of bending and rotating freely. A most interesting point for this work is the solvent-controlled assemblies of MOFs. The choice of solvents is an important parameter in the synthesis of MOFs and is the key to construct various coordination networks. Some organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, benzene, tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), and dimethylacetamide (DMA) are essential in coordination assemblies. They show specific acidity or basicity to modify the multicomponent reaction systems. In this work, under the influence of different solvents, the tci ligand exhibits different conformations and coordination modes. From the structural descriptions above, it shows the tci ligand is inclined to adopt cis, cis, cis-conformation in relatively small polar solvent and cis, cis, trans-conformation in relatively high polar solvent. With the increase of polarity of the solvents, the coordination number of tci decreases. Besides, it is notable to find that when the torsion angles of three propionic acid groups are larger than 160°, low-nuclear SBU tends to form. While high-nuclear SBUs are more apt to form when the torsion angles are smaller than 60°. Such varieties make these complexes exhibit different structures with different SBUs. Many researchers have demonstrated that the structural multiformity of complexes is undoubtedly related to the secondary ligand-directed inclusion. In the syntheses of complexes 5 and 6, rigid and semirigid N-donor ligands were introduced on the same syntheses conditions of complex 4 except the absence of NaOH. The coordination number of tci in 5 and 6 is four which is as the same as that in complex 4. And tci also adopt cis, cis, trans-conformation in 5 and 6. But under the influence of auxiliary ligands, the three propionic acid groups in tci cannot rotate freely, which results in low-nuclear Zn clusters. Therefore, the structural diversity for the Zn-MOFs based on different SBUs presented because of the various coordination modes of tci ligand. The results confirm that the solvent and coligands have important effects on the features and overall structures of Zn-MOFs, with respect to their constructions, flexibility, coordination modes, etc.

Effect of Different Solvent and Coligand

The prediction of polymer structures is still subjective and cannot be generalized because the final structures are frequently modulated by various factors, such as solvent, the metal and ligand nature, temperature, templates, and so on. Even for the same ligand and metal ion, changes in reaction conditions may give rise to the changes in the structural dimensionality of the products. Compared with the normal ligands, flexible ligands are very easy to be affected by the reaction conditions and have a tendency to generate different products even upon very little alteration of the reaction conditions. Herein, owing to the three flexible propionic acid groups, the tci molecule is capable of bending and rotating freely. A most interesting point for this work is the solvent-controlled assemblies of MOFs. The choice of solvents is an important parameter in the synthesis of MOFs and is the key to construct various coordination networks. Some organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, benzene, tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), and dimethylacetamide (DMA) are essential in coordination assemblies. They show specific acidity or basicity to modify the multicomponent reaction systems. In this work, under the influence of different solvents, the tci ligand exhibits different conformations and coordination modes. From the structural descriptions above, it shows the tci ligand is inclined to adopt cis, cis, cis-conformation in relatively small polar solvent and cis, cis, trans-conformation in relatively high polar solvent. With the increase of polarity of the solvents, the coordination number of tci decreases. Besides, it is notable to find that when the torsion angles of three propionic acid groups are larger than 160°, low-nuclear SBU tends to form. While high-nuclear SBUs are more apt to form when the torsion angles are smaller than 60°. Such varieties make these complexes exhibit different structures with different SBUs. Many researchers have demonstrated that the structural multiformity of complexes is undoubtedly related to the secondary ligand-directed inclusion. In the syntheses of complexes 5 and 6, rigid and semirigid N-donor ligands were introduced on the same syntheses conditions of complex 4 except the absence of NaOH. The coordination number of tci in 5 and 6 is four which is as the same as that in complex 4. And tci also adopt cis, cis, trans-conformation in 5 and 6. But under the influence of auxiliary ligands, the three propionic acid groups in tci cannot rotate freely, which results in low-nuclear Zn clusters. Therefore, the structural diversity for the Zn-MOFs based on different SBUs presented because of the various coordination modes of tci ligand. The results confirm that the solvent and coligands have important effects on the features and overall structures of Zn-MOFs, with respect to their constructions, flexibility, coordination modes, etc.

cln_elements.content:
A MeOH solution of Zn­(OAc)2 (10.95 mg in 3 mL) was carefully layered onto a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of H3tci (10.35 mg in 3 mL). After the solution was allowed to stand for about 7 days, the colorless crystals 1 formed were isolated in 73% yield by filtration. Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C38H60N10O24Zn3 (1237.07): C 36.89, H 4.88, N 11.32; found: C 36.19, H 4.42, N 11.12. IR: 3439s, 1690s, 1603m, 1470m, 1411m, 1251w, 1096w, 1021w, 963w, 766m, 531m.

A mixture of Zn­(OAc)2 (10.95 mg, 0.05 mmol), H3tci (10.35 mg, 0.03 mmol), H2O (1 mL), and DMSO (1 mL) were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 80 °C for 3 days, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in 69% yield. Elemental analysis (%): calcd. For C32H58N6O27S4Zn3 (1283.19): C 29.94, H 4.55, N 6.54; found: C 30.14, H 4.40, N 6.37. IR: 3487s, 1689s, 1601m, 1471m, 1398m, 1243w, 1148w, 947w, 756 m.

cln_elements.content: Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 3 crystallize in monoclinic space group P2/c. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn atom, one Na atom, and one tci ligand as well as three water molecules. Zn is coordinated four oxygen atoms from four individual carboxylate groups in μ3-η2:η1 conformation and one water molecule displaying distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry (τ = 0.88). Na shows octahedron geometry which is surrounded by five oxygen atoms from five individual tci ligands and one oxygen atom from the ring of the tci ligand (Figure a). The three carboxylate groups of tci ligand link four Zn atoms and five Na atoms via μ3-η2:η1 conformation. It is necessary to note that an infinite Zn–Na chain with Zn···Na separation of 3.486 Å is exhibited in the structure (Figure B). As a matter of fact, reports on this infinite Zn–Na chain as rod-shaped SBUs are rare to date. The connectivity between Zn–Na chains and tci ligands leads to the formation of a 2D double layer. It is interesting to find that there are two types of channels with different sizes along the b axis (Figure C). The crystallographic dimensions of the big channel are 8.318 × 5.335 Å2, while internal dimensions of the small channel are 4.214 × 7.216 Å2. Thus the guest water molecule can be encapsulated in the big channels. Adjacent 2D layers are connected by hydrogen bonding into a 3D supramolecular structure.
